page.title: 04FARMING ROUND CROFT.
page.content: The type of farming in the area varies a great deal. The alluvial soil near the River Tees is ideal for arable land, growing good crops of roots, particularly potatoes. Wheat and barley are also grown on this type of land and in recent years oilseed rape and a little linseed are used as break crops. At the other extreme the heavier clay is more suited to intensive grass farming. The grass is used both to graze livestock, such as dairy cows, beef cattle and sheep, and as a preserved winter feed in the form of silage and hay. Intensive pig units are to be found on some farms. Intensive beef units, where cattle are fattened on barley rather than grass, are also to be found. Most farms specialise in one main enterprise.
